newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina says U.S. to lift countervailing duties.
newsitem.headline: Argentina says U.S. to lift countervailing duties.

text.p: Argentine Economy Minister Roque Fernandez said Thursday U.S. Commerce Secretary William Daley told him Washington may soon lift trade sanctions on some Argentine products.
"He gave me no dates but he is optimistic about seeing good results for Argentina in the short term," Fernandez told reporters after talks with Daley, who Thursday kicked off a three-day visit.
He said U.S. countervailing duties on Argentine exports of products such as footwear and textiles could be lifted soon.

Daley, who earlier in the day met with Foreign Minister Guido Di Tella and in the evening was planning to hold talks with President Carlos Menem, did not speak to reporters. But he plans to hold a news conference Friday morning.
Argentina has been saying for weeks that the United States would soon revoke countervailing duties on imports of Argentine wool, hides, seamles steel tubes and rolled steel.

Fernandez and Daley also discussed a longstanding dispute over Argentina's patent laws, which Washington says fail to provide adequate protection against piracy of U.S. products. But the minister gave no details.
